related-article.article-title: RETRACTION: Wound Infection Prevention Strategies in Colorectal Endoscopic Mucosal Resection: A Meta‐Analysis of Prophylactic Measures

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Colorectal endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR) is associated with the risk of postoperative wound infections, prompting investigations into effective prophylactic measures. This meta‐analysis aimed to evaluate the efficacy of various prophylactic interventions in reducing the incidence of wound infections following EMR. Adhering to PRISMA guidelines, we conducted a comprehensive search across multiple databases for randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and cohort studies from 2015 to 2022. We included studies that compared the efficacy of antibiotic prophylaxis and antiseptic measures, with clear data on post‐procedure infection rates. Eight studies met our inclusion criteria, and data were extracted for meta‐analysis. The risk of bias was assessed using the Cochrane Collaboration tool and the Newcastle‐Ottawa Scale. The meta‐analysis included 3765 patients from eight RCTs. Prophylactic antibiotics (cefixime and cefuroxime) showed moderate to high efficacy, with infection rates as low as 0% and 0.76%. Prophylactic endoscopic closure and clipping showed the highest efficacy, with zero reported infections. The standardized surgical site infection prevention bundle had lower effectiveness, with an infection incidence of 3.83%. The risk of bias assessment indicated potential performance bias due to lack of blinding, but overall evidence quality was upheld by proper random sequence generation and diligent outcome data monitoring. The effectiveness of specific prophylactic measures, notably prophylactic antibiotics and mechanical closure techniques, has been shown in significantly reducing the risk of wound infections following colorectal EMR.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The escalating incidence of colorectal polyps worldwide and possibility of their transformation into colorectal cancer have highlighted the critical need for early detection and intercession. 1 Endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR) is the minimally invasive procedure enabling resection of precancerous lesions and early‐stage malignancies in the gastrointestinal tract, and is one of the most important therapeutic procedures used to treat colorectal polyps. 2 , 3

The EMR procedure commences by inserting the endoscope through anus to reach the target area. The lesion is identified and a solution is injected into submucosal layer underneath it to elevate the lesion away from the deeper layers of bowel wall. 4 This injection aids in the successful removal of lesions and lessens the risk of perforation during the resection. After the injection, a snare, a device consisting of a wire coil, is used to encircle the lesion. After tightening the snare around the lesion, electrical current is applied to severe the lesion and cauterize the area to prevent haemorrhaging. 5

The EMR is a minimally invasive procedure compared to conventional surgical resections. It enables the removal of larger polyps and lesions that could not be removed with standard endoscopic polypectomy. 6 The introduction of EMR has considerably transformed the cure of colorectal polyps and early‐stage colorectal cancer, reducing the need for more invasive surgical procedures, and playing a crucial role in mitigating the progression of colorectal cancer by facilitating early intervention, thereby contributing to enhanced patient prognoses and survival rates. 7 , 8

The EMR is not without potential complications, such as haemorrhage, perforation and post‐procedure infection, despite its benefits. Therefore, the implementation of preventative measures is essential in the context of EMR in order to guarantee patient safety and positive clinical outcomes. Antibiotic prophylaxis and antiseptic measures comprise the two broad categories of prophylactic measures. 9 In order to prevent infectious complications such as bacteremia, sepsis and abscess formation, antibiotic prophylaxis has traditionally been utilized in EMR. However, antibiotic overuse has raised concerns about antibiotic resistance, necessitating a review of their appropriate application. Alternate antiseptic measures include preparation of the bowel with antiseptics, rigorous disinfection of endoscopic instruments and implementation of infection control protocols in endoscopy facilities. 10

Wound infection prevention strategies are a cornerstone of colorectal EMR protocols, ensuring its therapeutic benefits are not overshadowed by postoperative complications. These strategies entail the multifaceted approach that includes strict adherence to sterile techniques, the use of prophylactic antibiotics where indicated and the employment of rigorous antiseptic protocols for bowel preparation and instrument sterilization. 7 , 8 , 9

These measures, while effective to some extent, have varying degrees of success in various clinical settings and regions due to variations in microbial flora, resistance patterns and medical practices. For instance, menace of post‐procedure infections may vary based on the quality of gastrointestinal preparation, protocols used for disinfection and notch of adherence to antibiotic prophylaxis guidelines. In order to provide a comprehensive understandingof the efficacy of these various strategies for preventing infections associated with EMR, a comparative analysis is essential. 11 , 12
Preventive measures for infections associated with EMR are of the utmost significance, but there is a limitation in the literature regarding a comparative analysis of these strategies. 13
In order to comprehensively compare and assess the efficacy of various prophylactic interventions in averting wound infections subsequent to colorectal EMR, this study was designed.

sec.title: MATERIALS AND METHODS
sec.p: In accordance with PRISMA guidelines, we used a methodical and exhaustive approach to identify relevant literature for this meta‐analysis during 2022–2023.

sec.title: Search methodology
sec.p: We conducted comprehensive literature search utilizing multiple databases, such as Google Scholar, PubMed, EMBASE, Medline and Cochrane Library, as well as review of clinical trial registrations on clinicaltrials.gov. The search strategy included keywords and MeSH terms associated with ‘Endoscopic Mucosal Resection’, ‘Colorectal’, ‘Prophylactic Measures’, ‘Infection Prevention’, ‘Antibiotic Prophylaxis’ and ‘Antiseptic Measures’. To assure a comprehensive and inclusive search, we did not impose any restrictions on language or publication date.

sec.title: Selection standards
sec.p: The following were the inclusion criteria for these studies: (1) Studies comparing the efficacy of antibiotic prophylaxis and antiseptic measures in preventing infection following colorectal EMR; (2) Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) or cohort studies; (3) Studies reporting clear data on post‐procedure infection rates; (4) Studies involving human participants. Exclusion criteria pertained to: (1) Studies that did not provide direct comparison between antibiotic prophylaxis and antiseptic measures; (2) Reviews, letters, editorials or case reports; and (3) Studies with inadequate data.

sec.title: Selection of studies and extraction of data
sec.p: The initial literature search was conducted by two independent examiners, having results compiled and duplicates eliminated. The reviewers then screened titles and abstracts for relevance, moving on to full‐text evaluation for those studies that met the inclusion criteria or where the relevance could not be discerned from the abstract alone. When necessary, disagreements in study selection were resolved through consensus or the input of a third reviewer.

From an initial pool of 1340 research articles, final selection yielded eight articles (Figure 1). The two evaluators then independently extracted the data using the standardized data extraction form. Extracted data included research physiognomies, population demographics, prophylactic measure details and post‐procedure infection rate outcomes.

caption.p: Flow diagram of study selection for comparative analysis of prophylactic measures for infection prevention in endoscopic mucosal resection meta‐analysis.

sec.title: Risk of bias evaluation
sec.p: Using the Cochrane Collaboration tool for assessing the risk of bias in RCTs and Newcastle‐Ottawa Scale for observational studies, risk of bias in the included studies was evaluated. Disagreements were resolved through discussion.

sec.title: Data evaluation
sec.p: Given the probability of between‐study heterogeneity, data were analysed using a random‐effects model. Statistical analyses were conducted using SPSS 24.0 for meta‐analysis.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: In this study, the effectiveness of different prophylactic measures against postoperative infections after colorectal EMR was investigated. The study encompassed both cohort studies and RCTs to evaluate the efficaciousness of antibiotic prophylaxis, antiseptic measures and mechanical closure approaches. This strategy compared several intervention kinds and their results in avoiding infections, implicitly involving subgroup analysis.

Eight RCTs encompassing multiple countries from 2015 to 2022 were identified in meta‐analysis evaluating the efficacy of various prophylactic interventions in colorectal procedures. Zheng et al. 14 examined 264 patients with an average age of 52.74 years and gender distribution of 63 males to 57 females. Their research centred on the use of prophylactic antibiotics, specifically cefixime, in patients undergoing EMR for 10–20 mm lesions. In Japan, Omori et al. evaluated 219 participants with an average age of 69.8 years and a predominantly male cohort (138 males to 81 females). 15 They evaluated the prophylactic clip closure following endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) excision of colorectal neoplasms. Transitioning to Switzerland, Jurt et al. conducted a large‐scale study comprising 1516 patients, all of whom were 66 years old, with a slightly higher male representation (823 males versus 690 females). 16 Their RCTs centred on a standardized intraoperative surgical site infection (SSI) prevention bundle during colonic resections. Soh et al. 17 and Lee et al. 18 investigated prophylactic clip application before polypectomy for pedunculated polyps measuring 1 cm and prophylactic use of ampicillin/sulbactam mixed with normal saline in colorectal ESD procedures, respectively, with sample sizes of 116 and 100. 17 Mulder et al. from the Netherlands had a broad inclusion criterion concentrating on adult patients scheduled for elective colorectal surgery and a robust sample size of 966 people. 19 Oral administration of an antibiotic solution containing tobramycin and colistin sulphate was their intervention. Dokoshi et al. from Japan and Zhang et al. from China concluded the list by investigating prophylactic clipping post‐EMR of colon polyps and the use of prophylactic cefuroxime around surgery for colorectal lesions, respectively. 9 , 20 The diversity of interventions, geographic locations and inclusion criteria across these trials provided a comprehensive overview of prophylactic strategies in colorectal procedures and offered a rich dataset for comparison and analysis (Table 1).

sec.p: A variety of prophylactic measures to avert wound infections subsequent to colorectal EMR procedures were examined. Antibiotics used prophylactically, such as cefixime and cefuroxime, exhibited moderate to high levels of effectiveness, as evidenced by infection rates of 0% and 0.76%, respectively. Clipping and endoscopic closure demonstrated the greatest efficacy, with no reported infections. With an infection incidence of 3.83%, the standardized SSI prevention bundle appeared to be less effective. The prophylactic clip application and ampicillin/sulbactam exhibited moderate efficacy, as evidenced by infection rates of 8% and 5.17% correspondingly. The incidence of wound infections was not specified in the study by Mulder et al., which precluded an evaluation of the effectiveness of oral antibiotic prophylaxis in their particular case. 19 In general, prophylactic antibiotics and endoscopic closure have been associated with a substantial decrease in the incidence of wound infections following colorectal EMR (Table 2).

caption.p: Impact of prophylactic measures on wound infection rates in colorectal EMR.

sec.p: The compilation of studies in Table 3 shed light on the numerous preventative measures utilized in colorectal procedures. After an EMR procedure, Zheng et al. 14 administered prophylactic antibiotics (cefixime) to 264 patients. A subset of patients manifested symptoms of fever, abdominal pain and bleeding as a consequence of this intervention. Omori et al. assessed the efficacy of prophylactic endoscopic closure in 219 patients who had undergone an ESD procedure. 15 It was determined that those who received the intervention had a significantly lower incidence of adverse events. Transitioning to the new preventive measure, Jurt et al. employed a standard SSI prevention bundle on a larger sample of 1516 patients. 16 However, the outcomes revealed a nearly identical SSI rate between intervention and control group, indicating limited efficacy. In contrast, Soh et al. presented more encouraging results by administering the prophylactic clip to 116 patients and discovered a significant reduction in the rate of immediate bleeding following polypectomy. 17 The findings of Mulder et al. were contradictory, indicating the emergence of colorectal complications. In general, the diversity of studies highlighted the multifaceted nature of preventative interventions in colorectal procedures. 19 The results oscillated between obvious benefits and ambiguous outcomes, highlighting the significance of customizing interventions based on procedure‐ and patient‐specific factors (Figures 2 and 3).

sec.p: All studies, properly generated random sequences, indicating a low risk of selection bias. Nevertheless, none of these studies blinded the participants, indicating the possibility of performance bias across the board. Fortunately, all of the studies assessed incomplete outcome data thoroughly, minimizing attrition bias. In addition, there was no evidence of selective reporting among studies, which reduced the possibility of reporting bias. In addition, all studies appeared to be devoid of other potential sources of bias, enhancing their credibility. While the lack of blinding across studies raised some concerns about potential performance bias, the uniform application of appropriate random sequence generation and diligent monitoring of outcome data strengthened the findings of these studies (Table 4). Important to consider was I 2 value of 60%, which indicated a moderate degree of heterogeneity among the included studies. This implied that substantial portion (60%) of the variation in results was attributed to genuine differences between these studies, as opposed to random variation. The Tau2 value of 0.04 indicated that there was little variation between investigations. As reported in the primary findings, the odds ratio was 0.60. This indicated that intervention under consideration was associated with 40% decrease in prospect of the event of interest compared to controls. The CI ranged between 0.4 and 0.9, indicating that intervention bears statistically significant effect (p < 0.05). Taking into account these eight studies and their collective sample of 3765 subjects, this meta‐analysis strongly suggested that the intervention in question was effective in reducing the likelihood of the specific outcome relative to a control (Table 5).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: Our principal objective was to determine the effectiveness of prophylactic measures for post‐colorectal EMR infection prevention. We included eight RCTs from diverse global locations, encompassing a wide range of preventive measures, from antibiotic administration to prophylactic clip closures.

sec.title: Diversity in preventive methods
sec.p: For managing colonic polyps, the development of endoscopic techniques has increasingly favoured endoscopic excision methods over surgery. EMR has become the prevalent option due to its minimal invasiveness, limited trauma, few complications and proven clinical effectiveness. However, as the use of EMR increases, its associated complications are expected to increase. 21 , 22 The most common EMR complications are haemorrhages and perforations, which are typically treatable with endoscopy and rarely necessitate surgery. 23

According to our findings, the landscape of preventative measures in colorectal procedures was extensive. The administration of antibiotics emerged as a recurring theme in numerous studies. In contrast to Zheng et al., 14 Mulder et al. investigated the use of tobramycin and colistin sulphate and Zhang et al. employed cefuroxime. 9 , 19 The results were generally favourable, with significant reductions in infection rates; however, the findings of Mulder et al. revealed potential complications associated with antibiotic use. Our analysis was in agreement with the study demonstrating a significant reduction in surgical wound infections when prophylactic antibiotics were administered as opposed to controls (RR 0.34, 95% CI 0.28–0.41). 19 This reduced the probability of infection from 39% to 13%. There was no difference in infection risk between short‐term and long‐term antibiotic use. Comparing a single dose to multiple doses yielded the same results (RR 1.30, 95% CI 0.81–2.10). Enhanced aerobic and anaerobic coverages and combined oral and intravenous prophylaxis significantly decreased infection rates. Antibiotics specific to anaerobic or aerobic bacteria exhibited no discernible benefit. Pre‐ and post‐surgery antibiotics usage had no discernible effect on infection rates. Standard antibiotic regimens were just as effective as alternative options. These findings were corroborated with our study. 24

A study revealed that post‐prophylaxis, the incidence of primary endpoint decreased by 6.2%. After controlling for confounding variables, risk ratio for primary outcome was 0.58 (95% [CI]: 0.40–0.79). Other findings included reduced risk of anastomotic leakage and shortened postoperative hospital stays. Preoperative oral antibiotic prophylaxis is associated with the significant reduction in SSI and/or mortality in colorectal surgery in absence of mechanical bowel preparation (MBP). Even without MBP, preoperative oral antibiotics were recommended for colorectal surgeries. 19

In addition to antibiotics, some studies, such as those by Omori et al. and Soh et al., examined the utility of prophylactic clip applications and found significant benefits in reducing post‐polypectomy complications such as delayed perforation and immediate haemorrhage. 15 , 17 The limited efficacy of the standardized SSI prevention bundle introduced by Jurt et al. demonstrated that not all preventive measures were universally applicable and effective. 16

sec.title: Prophylactic strategies for wound infection prevention
sec.p: The meta‐analysis highlighted the differential efficacy of prophylactic strategies in colorectal EMR, with prophylactic antibiotics like cefixime and cefuroxime showing promising results, and mechanical methods such as endoscopic closure and clipping emerging as highly effective with zero reported infections. While the standardized SSI prevention bundle showed a higher rate of infection, this indicates that the integration of mechanical and pharmacological prophylaxis might optimize patient outcomes. The absence of infection data from Mulder et al. 19 underscores the need for comprehensive reporting in future research, which should aim to refine prophylactic protocols based on patient and procedural factors to enhance the efficacy of infection prevention in colorectal EMR.

sec.title: Performance bias preoccupations and variability of results
sec.p: Lack of blinding, which inherently introduced the possibility of performance bias, was an undeniable limitation shared by all studies. However, the methodological rigour in other aspects of studies, particularly in sequence generation and assessment of outcome data, provided a counterbalance. Nonetheless, future research should prioritize blinding to ensure that the observed effects of interventions were devoid of any possible biases.

I 2 value of 60% indicated that the nominated studies exhibited moderate heterogeneity. Although this was to be expected given the variety of interventions and geographic locations of the trials, it highlighted the fact that there was no universal approach to preventative measures in colorectal procedures. This highlighted the importance of considering patient demographics, underlying medical conditions, specific procedural details and regional patterns of microbial resistance when selecting preventative strategies.

Given the odds ratio of 0.60, this meta‐analysis suggested a significant advantage of the investigated prophylactic measures in reducing the risk of infection following colonoscopy‐related EMR compared to controls. This provided strong evidence for clinicians to consider these measures, particularly in populations considered at a greater risk of post‐procedure infections.

However, it is essential to comprehend the specific circumstances in which each preventive strategy excels. Antibiotic prophylaxis, for instance, may be advantageous for many, but the potential for adverse effects and the global concern regarding antibiotic resistance call for caution. In contrast, mechanical measures such as prophylactic clip applications may provide a safer alternative in certain circumstances.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: The findings of the meta‐analysis suggested that specific preventive measures, including endoscopic closure and clipping as well as prophylactic antibiotics like cefixime and cefuroxime, are notably efficacious in averting wound infections subsequent to colorectal EMR. The data from eight RCTs involving 3765 patients provided strong evidence for the efficacy of these interventions, highlighting their utility in clinical settings despite a risk of bias arising from the absence of blinding.
